headline.main: A NASA SPACE CAMP FOR ASTRONAUT HOPEFULS

results.snippet: A longtime dream of the rocket pioneer Wernher von Braun has become a reality with the nation's first Space Camp, intended to interest boys and girls in aerospace careers. The eight weeklong camp sessions are continuing throughout the summer.  ...

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: A longtime dream of the rocket pioneer Wernher von Braun has become a reality with the nation's first Space Camp, intended to interest boys and girls in aerospace careers. The eight weeklong camp sessions are continuing throughout the summer. Seventy-five youngsters 12 through 14 years old spend the week in astronaut training at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Marshall Space Flight Center, where astronauts trained, and at the Alabama Space and Rocket Center, a state-run museum. They wear space suits, sample the freeze-dried food eaten in space and experience weightlessness. They are housed on the campus of the University of Alabama at Huntsville.

headline.main: ASTRONAUTS ABLE TO OPEN CARGO DOOR

results.snippet: The space shuttle Columbia's cargo bay doors worked perfectly in a second test of closing and opening today, reassuring the two astronauts that the structural warping seen Wednesday was a passing phenomenon caused by thermal conditions.   The...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Columbia's cargo bay doors worked perfectly in a second test of closing and opening today, reassuring the two astronauts that the structural warping seen Wednesday was a passing phenomenon caused by thermal conditions. The astronauts, Capt. Thomas K. Mattingly 2d of the Navy and Henry W. Hartsfield Jr., then fired rockets to raise the spaceship's orbit and put it on course for a scheduled landing Sunday at 12:09 P.M., New York time. President Reagan is expected to be at Edwards Air Force Base in California for the conclusion of the Columbia's fourth and final test flight. The second shuttle, in a planned fleet of at least four, was towed to the California base today from its assembly plant in Palmdale, Calif. The new vehicle, named Challenger, is scheduled to be flown piggyback on a Boeing 747 from Edwards to the Kennedy Space Center in Florida early next week. Its space debut is set for next January.

headline.main: REHEARSAL IN SPACESUIT GOES WELL FOR ASTRONAUT

results.snippet: The commander of the space shuttle Columbia entered an airlock, donned his full pressure suit and rehearsed other procedures today for going outside the spaceship, an activity that is to be practiced in reality on the next shuttle flight.   Capt....

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The commander of the space shuttle Columbia entered an airlock, donned his full pressure suit and rehearsed other procedures today for going outside the spaceship, an activity that is to be practiced in reality on the next shuttle flight. Capt. Thomas K. Mattingly 2d of the Navy reported that he had no trouble getting in and out of the bulky spacesuit. The suits are carried along in case the astronauts have to go outside to make repairs or secure the latches on the cargo bay doors. In addition, Captain Mattingly and his co-pilot, Henry W. Hartsfield Jr., put the shuttle's 50-foot-long robot arm to another test, fired the spaceship's maneuvering jets to assess their performance and monitored instruments in the secret military payload being carried by the Columbia.

headline.main: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Columbia Gets It Right - but At a High Cost

results.snippet: After more than a decade of research, development and testing that cost well over $10 billion, the space shuttle was headed for operational status today upon landing at Edwards Air Force Base. Its fourth evaluation flight, which mission controllers...

byline.original: By Wayne Biddle and Margot Slade

results.lead_paragraph: After more than a decade of research, development and testing that cost well over $10 billion, the space shuttle was headed for operational status today upon landing at Edwards Air Force Base. Its fourth evaluation flight, which mission controllers called the ''cleanest'' of the program, had demonstrated the military and commercial hybrid that now characterizes America's presence in space. Shortly after leaving on time from Cape Canaveral last Sunday, the shuttle experienced the kind of malfunction that raises questions about the system's economic viability, if not its technical perfection. Two booster rockets valued at $25 million each, which were designed for refurbishment as a cost-saving measure, plunged to the bottom of the ocean after their parachutes failed. When added to the approximately $12 million price of the external fuel tank sloughed off at the end of the orbiter's ascent, this meant that the ''reusable'' shuttle expended at least $62 million worth of hardware during launch. NASA officials did not expect the booster accident to delay future missions, but the agency is under heavy pressure to make the shuttle economical.

headline.main: REALITY IS ALSO A STAR IN MOVIE 'THE RIGHT STUFF'

results.snippet: SAN FRANCISCO GLENN FARR sits at a shiny silver metal table amid boxes of redand-yellow plastic film cores. For 12 hours a day, his world is the acrid environment of an editing room, where rolls of film twisting back and forth always leave a...
results.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO GLENN FARR sits at a shiny silver metal table amid boxes of redand-yellow plastic film cores. For 12 hours a day, his world is the acrid environment of an editing room, where rolls of film twisting back and forth always leave a slightly burnt smell in the air. It is Mr. Farr's job to braid old newsreels, National Aeronautics and Space Administration film of the astronauts, historical moments and the newly minted reality of actors playing the astronauts into ''The Right Stuff'' - the Ladd Company's $17 million movie about the first Americans in space which is due to open next spring. Although television has occasionally attempted something similar, this movie from Tom Wolfe's best-selling book is singular for a film in the age of real events with close-up shots by a Hollywood director in technical as well as dramatic terms. To Leave Audiences Shaken An average 1-hour-54-minute movie contains approximately 10,000 feet of film. Stacked in bins on the walls of the cavernous former cannery that is ''The Right Stuff's'' headquarters are 600 fat rolls of stock footage - 500,000 feet of reality from the past. To get the 500,000 feet, Mr. Farr looked at ''hundreds of miles of film'' at the National Archives in Washington and at ''at least one million of NASA's nine million feet of film.''

results.snippet: President Reagan, saying nations in the Caribbean face ''grave economic problems and political instability,'' told a group of diplomats and American businessmen tonight that in the next few weeks he would ''personally'' seek to win Congressional...

byline.original: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: President Reagan, saying nations in the Caribbean face ''grave economic problems and political instability,'' told a group of diplomats and American businessmen tonight that in the next few weeks he would ''personally'' seek to win Congressional approval of his Caribbean trade and aid plan. ''I consider passage of that program a top priority,'' Mr. Reagan said in remarks at a reception at the Organization of American States. The reception was sponsored by the Caribbean Basin Initiative Coalition, a private group of major American businesses seeking to increase trade and investment in the region.

headline.main: Boy Born in Houston To Astronaut Couple

results.snippet: A 7-pound, 2-ounce boy was born today to the astronauts Margaret Rhea Seddon and Robert L.  Gibson at a hospital near here.
results.lead_paragraph: A 7-pound, 2-ounce boy was born today to the astronauts Margaret Rhea Seddon and Robert L. Gibson at a hospital near here.

results.snippet: Paul Seddon Gibson, the first child born to an American astronaut, was reported doing very well today in Hermann Hospital, where he was being treated for minor breathing difficulties. The baby, born Monday to Margaret Rhea Seddon, was expected to...
results.lead_paragraph: Paul Seddon Gibson, the first child born to an American astronaut, was reported doing very well today in Hermann Hospital, where he was being treated for minor breathing difficulties. The baby, born Monday to Margaret Rhea Seddon, was expected to leave the hospital in about a week and a half, a spokesman at the Johnson Space Center said. The father, Robert Gibson, is also an astronaut.
